etymology.description: 言(言) (yán, "word") + something in 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") written like 甘(甘) = sound coming from the mouth -> vertical trait representing tongue disappeared -> 甘 stylized as 曰 -> final form
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicting words or sounds coming from the mouth with an implied symbolic depiction of the tongue, the character evolved by stylizing the components. The progression from 甘(甘) to 曰 indicates a refinement in the depiction of sound production over time.

examples.chinese: 在合成汉字中(在合成漢字中)，音决定读音(音決定讀音)。
examples.pinyin: Zài héchéng hànzì zhōng, yīn juédìng dúyīn.
examples.english: In compound characters, the phonetic component determines the pronunciation.

examples.chinese: 这个字的音使我们联想到原始发音(這個字的音使我們聯想到原始發音)。
examples.pinyin: Zhège zì de yīn shǐ wǒmen liánxiǎng dào yuánshǐ fàyīn.
examples.english: The phonetic component of this character reminds us of its original pronunciation.
